facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 10 of 1950 filed in Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 10 of 1950. Appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment of High Court of Punjab by Falshaw and Soni JJ dated 30th December 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab  Falshaw and Soni JJ.  dated 30th December, 1949, upholding the conviction of the appellant under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34

facts.text: High Court upheld conviction under sections 302 and 307 read with section 34 IPC and confirmed death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: upholding the conviction of the appellant under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 of the Indian Penal Code and confirming the sentence of death passed against him by the Sessions Judge

facts.text: Sessions Judge of Ferozepore passed death sentence on appellant on 20th July 1949 in Criminal Appeal Case No. 325 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: passed against him by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore on the 20th July, 1949, in Criminal Appeal Case No. 325 of 1949.

facts.text: Prosecution case: Sometime in January 1949, Bachittar Singh lodged complaint before Naib Tehsildar at Zira that tree cut by 7 persons including Mohinder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in January, 1949, one Bachittar Singh, brother of Dalip Singh who is said, to have been murdered, lodged a complaint before the NaibTehsildar at Zira to the effect that a tree belonging to him had been cut by 7 per- sons including Mohinder Singh, the appellant.

facts.text: On 28th February 1949, date fixed for hearing before Naib Tehsildar, Jita Singh and Dalip Singh attacked by appellant Mohinder Singh and Gurnam Singh near Gurdwara at mid-day while returning from field.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th February, 1949, which was the date fixed for the hearing of the case before the Naib TehsiIdar, Jita Singh and Dalip Singh, the two brothers of Bachittar Singh, were attacked by the appellant and one Gurnam Singh, a lad of 17, near a Gurdwara at about mid-day, when they were returning from their field.

facts.text: Jita Singh carrying load of fodder on head, Dalip Singh had sickles in hand.

anchor.surface_text: Jita Singh was then carrying a load of fodder on his head while Dalip Singh had sickles in his hand.

facts.text: Mohinder Singh fired at Jita Singh from behind near tailors shop, hitting neck, Jita fell down.

anchor.surface_text: Jita Singh was the first to be at- tacked near a tailors shop by Mohinder Singh who fired at him from behind hitting him on the neck whereupon he fell down together with the bundle of fodder.

facts.text: Dalip Singh ran backwards, chased by Gurnam Singh round tank boundary; Mohinder ran other side and shot Dalip on chest.

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh, who was following Jita Singh, then ran backwards and he was chased by Gurnam Singh round the outer boundary of a tank which was close by. Mohinder Singh ran on the other side of the tank in the opposite direction and confronted him and shot him with a gun on the chest whereupon he fell down.

facts.text: Gurnam Singh fired rifle at Dalip Singh from 4-5 feet near ear while lying sideways.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, Gurnam Singh had also reached the spot and he fired with his rifle from a distance of about 4 or 5 feet near about Dalip Singhs ear while he was lying sideways.

facts.text: Dalip Singh died on the spot.

anchor.surface_text: The injuries proved fatal and Dalip Singh died on the spot.

facts.text: Same day at 3 p.m., Jita Singh lodged first information report at police station Dharamkot, 3 miles from village Augar.

anchor.surface_text: The same day at 3 p.m., Jita Singh went to the police station at Dharamkot, which is at a distance of 3 miles from village Augar, where the occurrence had taken place, and lodged a first information report, charging Mohinder Singh,

facts.text: Police investigated and sent charge-sheet against Mohinder Singh and Gurnam Singh.

anchor.surface_text: charging Mohinder Singh, with having caused injury to him, and Mohinder Singh and Gurnam Singh with the murder of Dalip Singh and the police after investigating the case sent up a charge-sheet against the two accused persons.

facts.text: Tried by Sessions Judge Ferozepore under ss 302 and 307 r/w 34 IPC; appellant sentenced to death, Gurnam to transportation for life, both 3 years RI under 307/34.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter they were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore under sections 302 and 307 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. The appellant was sentenced to death under section 302 and Gurnam Singh was sentenced to transportation for life under that section in view of his youth. They were also sentenced to 3 years rigorous imprisonment each under section 307 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Dalip Singh had 6 gunshot injuries as described by doctor in post-mortem.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Dalip Singh had 6 injuries altogether which are described by the doctor who performed the post- mortem on his body in these words- An irregularly round gun shot wound on the left temporal region, 1 diameter. The wound is 22 behind outer canthus of left eye, its upper portion is at a level with the top of the pinna of the left ear, behind it commences at the cartilages of the ear which are broken.

facts.text: Doctor opined two projectiles hit Dalip Singh: injuries 1-2 by one (entrance temporal, exit mastoid); 3-6 by another (entrance chest left, exit right chest, re-entrance arm, exit front arm).

anchor.surface_text: The doctor has stated in his evidence that in all two projectiles appeared to have hit Dalip Singh, and injuries Nos. 1 and 2 were caused by one of them, injury No. 1 being the wound of entrance and injury No. 2 being the wound of exit, With regard to the other 4 injuries, his evidence is as follows - Injury No. 3 is the wound of entrance of another projectile and No. 4 is the wound of its exit. Wound No. 5 is the wound of its re-entrance and wound No. 6 the wound of its final exit from the body.

facts.text: Jita Singh had 4 slight pellet injuries on back of neck and two abrasions below right elbow and knee.

anchor.surface_text: Jita Singh had 4 slight injuries on the back of the neck which are said to have been caused by pellets and two abra- sions below the right elbow and right knee said to have been caused by blunt weapons.

facts.text: Police found empty cartridge case where Jita shot at, 2 empty cases and blood-stained cap near Dalip body.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that when the investigating police officer arrived at the scene of occurrence, he found an empty cartridge case at the place where Jita Singh is said to have been fired at, and 2 empty cartridge cases and a blood-stained cap of a cartridge case near the place where the dead body of Dalip Singh was lying.

facts.text: Mohinder Singh produced 12 bore gun P-16 for which he held licence.

anchor.surface_text: Later, when Mohinder Singh appeared before the police, he was asked whether he possessed a gun and he produced a 12 bore gun  exhibit P-16  for which he held a licence.

facts.text: Dr Goyle opined gun P-16 had signs of firing but couldn't say when; cartridges P-10 P-15 could have been from P-16 or similar.

anchor.surface_text: The gun and the empty cartridges were thereupon sent to Dr. Goyle, Director of the C.I.D. Laboratory, Phillaur, and the opinion that he submitted may be summed up as follows --The gun had signs of having been fired but he could number say when it was fired last. The cartridge cases P-10 and P-15 could have been fired through the gun P-16, but he could number say wheth- er they were actually fired from that particular gun or a similar gun or guns.

facts.text: Occurrence near Gurdwara and houses but no local witnesses examined; case rests on Jita Singh, Harnam Singh, Buta Singh.

anchor.surface_text: A numberable feature of the case is that the occurrence is said to have taken place in the vicinity of a Gurdwara and some houses, but in spite of this fact, number a single person of the locality has been cited or examined as a witness by the prosecution. The whole case rests on the evidence of 3 witnesses, viz., Jita Singh, Harnam Singh and Buta Singh.

facts.text: Appellant denied firing and claimed alibi: not present in Augar but in Zira at Naib Tehsildar court.

anchor.surface_text: After the close of prosecution evidence in the Ses- sions Court, the appellant was examined under section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and he denied that he had fired at Jita Singh and Dalip Singh with the gun P-16 and that Gurnam Singh had fired at Dalip Singh with a rifle. He added that he was number present in village Augur at the time of the alleged occurrence but had gone to Zira to attend the Naib Tehsildars court.

facts.text: Appellant examined 3 alibi witnesses: Naib Tehsildar, brother-in-law Jogindar Singh, handwriting expert.

anchor.surface_text: To establish his plea of alibi, he examined 3 witnesses in the court of the Sessions Judge. The first witness was the Naib Tehsildar before whom Bachittar Singh had lodged the complaint, and he stated that when the case was called on the 28th February, 1949, 6 or 7 persons appeared in court. He also proved an application for a taccavi loan which purports to have been filed by the appel- lant on the 28th February, 1949, and bears his thumb impres- sion.

facts.text: Lower courts held alibi not proved, charges made out.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have held that the alibi has number been proved by satisfactory evidence and that the charges against the appellant have been made out.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 17, 1950 by Fazl Ali J.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. October 17. The judgment of the court was deliv- ered by FAZL ALI J.--This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab upholding the convic- tion of the appellant.
under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 of the Indian Penal Code

issues.text: Whether the prosecution proved by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to Dalip Singh to have been caused with the alleged weapons (gun P-16 and rifle) and in the manner alleged by the eyewitnesses

anchor.surface_text: in a case where death is due to injuries or wounds caused by a lethal weapon, it has always been considered to be the duty of the prosecution to prove by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon with which and in the manner in which they are alleged to have been caused.

issues.text: Whether the two shots fired at Dalip Singh were proved to have been fired by two persons (Mohinder Singh with gun and Gurnam Singh with rifle) rather than by one man

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, and it is also the prosecution case, that only 2 shots were fired at Dalip Singh and one of the crucial points which the prosecution had to prove was that these shots were fired by two persons and not by one man

issues.text: Whether this Court should entertain the criminal appeal under its special leave jurisdiction given the limited scope for interference in criminal matters
Whether the courts below disposed of the plea of alibi in accordance with the required standard of proof, namely the same reasonable standard as applied to the prosecution evidence

arguments.claim: The alibi has not been proved by satisfactory evidence and the charges against the appellant have been made out

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have held that the alibi has not been proved by satisfactory evidence and that the charges against the appellant have been made out.

arguments.court_reasoning: Decision on plea of alibi arrived at in disregard of principle that standard of proof must be the same reasonable standard as applied to prosecution evidence

arguments.claim: The evidence of Dr. Goyle is unsatisfactory and we are not confident that the gun exhibit P-16 had been used in causing the injuries

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the learned Judges of the High Court were not at all impressed by the evidence of Dr. Goyle which they characterized as unsatisfactory and they were not also confident that the gun, exhibit P-16, had been used

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed there are puzzling features but emphasizes prosecution duty for expert evidence which was lacking

arguments.claim: The gun P-16 identification by brass plate is unreliable as it could be of no use for identification

anchor.surface_text: The gun P-16 was identified by Jita Singh as the gun with which Mohinder Singh fired at him and Dalip Singh but he identified the gun because of a brass plate at its butt end. We have seen the gun. Its brass plate could be of no

arguments.claim: The nature of injuries creates difficulty; unknown bullet type that blackened but did not shatter brain, projectile passed through without extensive damage despite close range

anchor.surface_text: Another difficulty which is created in this case is the nature of injuries found on the body of Dalip Singh What kind of bullet it was which, though it had blackened the area where it entered the brain showing that it had been fired from not far away, did not shatter the brain we do not know.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e date fixed for dealing with Bachittar Singhs companyplaint. Ordinarily and without looking at anything else, there should have been numberhing impro

arguments.court_reasoning: Learned Judges strongly felt no adequate explanation in oral evidence for puzzling features of injuries

arguments.claim: Firing must have been from 600 to 1,200 yards away for projectile to pass through without shattering, based on Taylor's medical jurisprudence and Hatcher's ballistics

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sethi counsel for the accused quoted Taylors book on medical jurisprudence and Hatehers book on ballistics and argued that the firing must have been from a place between 600 and 1,200 yards away in order that the projectile may pass through and through the body and not shatter it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ant. This allega- tion companyld have been substantiated in the cross-examina- tion of the Naib Tehsildar who was examined as a defence witness, but n

arguments.court_reasoning: Supports need for expert evidence on possibility of injuries at close range

arguments.claim: In cases of death by lethal weapon injuries, prosecution has duty to prove by expert evidence that injuries likely or possible with alleged weapon and manner

anchor.surface_text: in a case where death is due to injuries or wounds caused by a lethal weapon, it has always been considered to be the duty of the prosecution to prove by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon with which and in the manner in which they are alleged to have been caused.

arguments.claim: Prosecution had to prove the two shots at Dalip Singh were fired by two persons (Mohinder with gun, Gurnam with rifle) not one man, in alleged manner and distance

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, and it is also the prosecution case, that only 2 shots were fired at Dalip Singh and one of the crucial points which the prosecution had to prove was that these shots were fired by two persons and not by one man, and both the shots were fired in such manner and from such distance

arguments.claim: Courts below erred by ignoring gap in prosecution evidence on fundamental point and deciding merely on oral evidence of three witnesses who are chance/partisan

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, a gap in the prosecution evidence on a most fundamental point and the error which has been committed by the courts below is to ignore the gap and decide the case merely upon the oral evidence of 3 witnesses, two of whom are mere chance witnesses and not altogether independent persons,

arguments.claim: This Court will not entertain criminal appeal except in special exceptional cases of disregard of legal process, violation of natural justice, or substantial grave injustice
Present case comes within exceptional rule as conviction despite wanting evidence on material part of prosecution case
Decision on plea of alibi disregarded principle that standard of proof required is same reasonable standard as for prosecution evidence
Appellant not present at occurrence but in Zira at Naib Tehsildar's court, proved by alibi witnesses, taccavi application with thumb impression filed that day

anchor.surface_text: After the close of prosecution evidence in the Sessions Court, the appellant was examined under section 342 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and he denied that he had fired at Jita Singh and Dalip Singh with the gun P-16 and that Gurnam Singh had fired at Dalip Singh with a rifle. He added that he was not present in village Augur

arguments.court_reasoning: Improper disposal by lower courts; evidence supported by probability and document though witness related

arguments.claim: Original service report of process peon suppressed and forged one substituted

anchor.surface_text: The evidence given by him with regard to these handwritings has a bearing on the assertion made by the appellant in a petition filed before the committing Magistrate to the effect that the original service report of the process peon showing that the appellant also was one of the persons served

arguments.claim: Process peon's evidence suspicious as conveniently forgotten material details

holdings.text: In a case where death is due to injuries or wounds caused by a lethal weapon, it has always been considered to be the duty of the prosecution to prove by expert evidence that it was likely or at least possible for the injuries to have been caused with the weapon with which and in the manner in which they are alleged to have been caused.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying long-established practice requiring expert evidence to link lethal weapons to specific injuries and manner of use.

holdings.text: The evidence adduced falls short of proof in regard to a very material part of the prosecution case, particularly whether the injuries were caused by a gun or rifle and at close range.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No expert evidence to confirm possibility of alleged injuries from specific weapons (gun P-16 or rifle) at described distances; puzzling injury features unaddressed.

holdings.text: Only 2 shots were fired at Dalip Singh, and the prosecution failed to prove these were fired by two persons (appellant with gun and Gurnam with rifle) rather than one, in the alleged manner and distance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution case requires proof of joint action via s.34 but lacks expert linkage of injuries to two distinct weapons; gap ignores eyewitness oral evidence alone insufficient.

holdings.text: There is a gap in the prosecution evidence on a most fundamental point; courts below erred by ignoring it and resting conviction on unchecked oral testimony of three witnesses.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fundamental evidentiary gap on weapon-injury nexus cannot be bridged by partisan/chance eyewitnesses without expert corroboration.

holdings.text: This Court will not entertain a criminal appeal except in special and exceptional cases where there is manifest disregard of legal process, violation of natural justice, or substantial grave injustice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Pritam Singh v. State limiting appellate interference.

holdings.text: The present case comes within the exceptional rule permitting interference, as the appellant was convicted notwithstanding evidence wanting on a most material part of the prosecution case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidentiary gap on core prosecution elements constitutes grave injustice warranting Supreme Court intervention under Art.136.

holdings.text: The standard of proof required for a plea of alibi must be the same reasonable standard as applied to prosecution evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of equal reasonable proof standards for defence and prosecution; lower courts disregarded in evaluating alibi evidence.

holdings.text: The courts below disposed of the plea of alibi in disregard of the required standard of proof.

anchor.surface_text: we find that in the present case the decision on the plea of alibi has been arrived at in disregard of the principle that the standard of proof

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alibi supported by probability, document (taccavi application with thumb impression), and witness testimony despite relation; lower courts improperly rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singh v. The State  1

precedents.cited_proposition: This Court will not entertain a criminal appeal except in special and exceptional cases where it is manifest that by a disregard of the forms of legal process or by a violation of the principles of natural justice or otherwise substantial and grave injustice has been done
